junityahoo@... wrote:
> 
> I�d like to clarify that I never meant to assert that:

> a)      I was going to figure out how to do something with Junit that 
> everyone else
> previously was incapable of.

> b)      Junit was expected to solve my every testing problem.

But can you understand why what you wrote could have come across that 
way? It was pretty clear to me.

> Rather than deem Junit insufficient, my first thought was that I was missing
> something.  This stance was taken out of respect for �all the very smart 
> people
> who've been working with JUnit since 1999.�  The reason that I asked on this
> forum is to �take some stock in what someone with experience has to say.�
> I was expecting some explanation of why this type of testing was not 
> supported.

OK. Did you get the explanation you wanted? Sometimes the explanation 
takes pages and pages, and I don't have the energy to write that out 
every time someone asks.

> Maybe that there were better paradigms that Junit preferred.  I was simply
> trying to best understand a piece of software before moving on.
> I guess I'm confused about your need to be condescending, especially 
> since my
> motivations to respect previous work, listen to experience, and recognize
> software limitations seem to line up pretty nicely with your views.
> Thanks for you time, I guess I'll have to wait until you explain the 
> solutions
> that you alluded to.

I apologize for my tone. I was tired, and it seemed like you were asking 
for our advice, then disregarding it anyway. You can understand how that 
might be enervating.
--
